member.name: Windows.timeBeginPeriod
member.summary: The timeBeginPeriod function requests a minimum resolution for periodic timers.
member.param: Minimum timer resolution, in milliseconds, for the application or device driver. A lower value specifies a higher (more accurate) resolution.
member.returns: Returns TIMERR_NOERROR if successful or TIMERR_NOCANDO if the resolution specified in uPeriod is out of range.

member.name: Windows.timeEndPeriod
member.summary: The timeEndPeriod function clears a previously set minimum timer resolution.
member.param: Minimum timer resolution specified in the previous call to the function.
member.returns: Returns TIMERR_NOERROR if successful or TIMERR_NOCANDO if the resolution specified in uPeriod is out of range.

member.name: Windows.timeGetDevCaps
member.summary: The timeGetDevCaps function queries the timer device to determine its resolution.
member.param: A pointer to a structure. This structure is filled with information about the resolution of the timer device.
The size, in bytes, of the structure.

returns.para: Returns MMSYSERR_NOERROR if successful or an error code otherwise. Possible error codes include the following.

listheader.description: The ptc parameter is NULL, or the cbtc parameter is invalid, or some other error occurred.

member.name: Windows.timeGetSystemTime
member.summary: The timeGetSystemTime function retrieves the system time, in milliseconds. The system time is the time elapsed since Windows was started. This function works very much like the function. See timeGetTime for details of these functions' operation.
member.param: Size, in bytes, of the MMTIME structure.
member.returns: If successful, returns TIMERR_NOERROR. Otherwise, returns an error code.

member.name: Windows.timeGetTime
member.summary: The timeGetTime function retrieves the system time, in milliseconds. The system time is the time elapsed since Windows was started.
member.returns: Returns the system time, in milliseconds.
